title: 4-Photon Boson Sampling Experiment
description: Demonstrates quantum computational advantage by interfering 4 indistinguishable photons through a 4-mode linear optical network and measuring output statistics

parameters.description: Time-tagging module that records all 4 detector outputs with sub-nanosecond resolution and identifies 4-fold coincidence events to construct output probability distribution

physics_explanation: Two SPDC sources generate four heralded single photons at 810nm that are coupled into single-mode fibers to ensure spatial and temporal indistinguishability. Each photon pair is split by input beam splitters to populate all four input modes of a linear optical network. The network consists of three layers of beam splitters with programmable phase shifters that implement a random unitary transformation U. Quantum interference causes the photons to evolve according to the permanent of the 4×4 matrix U, a computation that is classically intractable. Superconducting nanowire detectors measure all four output modes, and coincidence logic identifies 4-photon events, producing a probability distribution that validates quantum computational advantage.

component_justifications.Pump Laser 1: 405nm CW laser pumps first SPDC source to generate photon pairs at 810nm through frequency down-conversion
component_justifications.Pump Laser 2: Second independent 405nm pump laser for second SPDC source to generate additional photon pairs
component_justifications.SPDC Crystal 1: PPLN crystal with type-0 phase matching generates spectrally pure heralded single photons via spontaneous parametric down-conversion
component_justifications.SPDC Crystal 2: Second PPLN crystal produces additional photon pairs, enabling 4-photon input state when heralded
component_justifications.Filter 1: Narrowband interference filter at 810nm blocks pump light and selects desired SPDC wavelength with 3nm bandwidth
component_justifications.Filter 2: Second narrowband filter ensures spectral indistinguishability between photons from different sources
component_justifications.Fiber Coupler 1: Single-mode fiber coupling ensures spatial mode matching and temporal indistinguishability of photons
component_justifications.Fiber Coupler 2: Second fiber coupler for photons from second source, maintaining mode quality
component_justifications.Input BS 1: Splits first photon pair into modes 1 and 2 to populate upper two input modes of the 4-mode network
component_justifications.Input BS 2: Splits second photon pair into modes 3 and 4 to populate lower two input modes of the 4-mode network
component_justifications.Phase 1: First layer phase shifter for mode 1 provides 0-2π phase control for implementing arbitrary unitary
component_justifications.Phase 2: First layer phase shifter for mode 2 enables independent phase control
component_justifications.Phase 3: First layer phase shifter for mode 3 provides phase tuning capability
component_justifications.Phase 4: First layer phase shifter for mode 4 completes first layer phase control across all modes
component_justifications.Network BS 1-2: Couples modes 1 and 2 with 33% transmittance to create interference between upper modes
component_justifications.Network BS 2-3: Couples modes 2 and 3 with 67% transmittance for central mode interference
component_justifications.Network BS 3-4: Couples modes 3 and 4 with 50:50 splitting for lower mode interference
component_justifications.Phase 5: Second layer phase shifter for mode 1 after first beam splitter layer
component_justifications.Phase 6: Second layer phase shifter for mode 2 provides additional phase control
component_justifications.Phase 7: Second layer phase shifter for mode 3 enables complex unitary transformations
component_justifications.Phase 8: Second layer phase shifter for mode 4 completes two-layer phase control
component_justifications.Output BS 1-2: Final layer 50:50 beam splitter couples modes 1 and 2 for output interference
component_justifications.Output BS 2-3: Final layer 50:50 beam splitter couples modes 2 and 3 for output interference
component_justifications.Output BS 3-4: Final layer 50:50 beam splitter couples modes 3 and 4 for output interference
component_justifications.SNSPD 1: Superconducting nanowire single-photon detector for mode 1 with 85% efficiency and 50ps timing resolution
component_justifications.SNSPD 2: High-efficiency SNSPD for mode 2 enables low-loss photon detection
component_justifications.SNSPD 3: SNSPD for mode 3 with minimal dark counts for high-fidelity measurements
component_justifications.SNSPD 4: SNSPD for mode 4 with excellent timing resolution for coincidence detection
component_justifications.4-Channel Coincidence Logic: Time-tagging electronics process all detector signals to identify 4-fold coincidence events within 2ns window and construct output probability distribution for comparison with permanent calculation

expected_outcome: The measured 4-photon output distribution will show characteristic boson bunching patterns that match the permanent of the network's 4×4 unitary matrix. Certain output configurations will have enhanced or suppressed probabilities compared to distinguishable particles. The distribution cannot be efficiently simulated classically, demonstrating quantum computational advantage. Validation involves comparing measured statistics with permanent calculations for the implemented unitary transformation.
